title.narrative: Central African Republic Joint Response, Phase 4

description.narrative: Target Groups Description FSL activities (incl. mainstreamed protection) target vulnerable HHs that have arrived in/ returned to Ouham Pende during the last 3 months and that have limited livelihoods options as most assets were lost when fleeing their homes. Other targeted vulnerable HHs are female- and child-headed HH, pregnant or lactating women, people with disabilities, people with HIV, elderly people and those hosting orphans. Child Protection activities target vulnerable children that are affected by the fragile context in CAR. Many have lost one/both of their parents and are now head of the HH and taking care of siblings. Host families who take in UASC are often already poor, so that HH vulnerability increases when hosting these children.

The CARJR4 has two Strategic Objectives (SO1 and SO2): Objective 1: To alleviate human suffering of the population of the Central African Republic through the effective and efficient implementation of humanitarian response activities by the Dutch NGOs. Objective 2: To generate value through the collaboration between the CARJR4 members and other stakeholders.

World Vision contributes to the following objectives: Protection, Objective 2: Conflict affected populations have access to protection according to fundamental Human Rights (inclusive of GBV and Children's rights) as well as to effective prevention mechanisms upholding their security and dignity Protection, Objective 3: Reinforce the protection mechanisms at community level as well as access to basic services Food Security & Livelihoods,Objective 1: Safe lives and contribute to the economic autonomy of the population

% of budget that went to national and local actors. Please use Grand Total Budget (incl ICR) to calculate this percentage. National and local responders comprise governments, communities, Red Cross and Red Crescent National Societies and local civil society. National and local responders do not include local offices of INGOs.

title.narrative: % of budget that went to national and local actors

description.narrative: Femme Juriste, local partner, will be responsible for the beneficiary identification for the GBV response

1. Crisis affected children have acces to emergency services to safeguard their protection. 2. Protection of affected children at risk of human rights violation is assured. 3. Community & national child protection mechanisms are reinforced and ensure quality services respecting human dignity and resilience of children and the communities they live in. 1) This indicator covers response to children (girls and boys under 18). 2) Appropriate response is defined as the provision of comprehensive services/assistance based on a thorough analysis of the risks faced by persons. The protection outcome of the response must be well defined. Relevant SOPs (including functional Referral Mechanism) should be followed. 3) Use the comments field to to describe what services (medical, MHPSS, legal, security, etc.), as well as SOPs are in place. Activities can include psychosocial support to children, Child Friendly Spaces and support to parents to fulfill their protection responsibilities towards their children. 4) Number of persons must be disaggregated by sex at reporting stage.5) If action also includes prevention activities, please describe this within the activity under this indicator.

title.narrative: #Number of children that received support specified to their needs

description.narrative: Activity 6: Child Friendly Spaces (05) are set up with regards to Child Protection minimum standards and providing psychosocial assistance to children with trauma or in distress situation. 4 will be build and 1 will be rehabilitated. Activity 6.1: Build 4 Child Friendly Spaces Activity 6.2: Rehabilitate 1 Child Friend Spaces Activity 6.3: Support (psychosocial) the social and administrative services involving in child protection management such as sexual violence, physical violence and exploitation. Activity 6.4: Assist 5 schools for the enrollment of vulnerable children such as demobilized children, survivors of protection incidents who can still return to school Activity 6.5: Train Project staff and monitors in psycho social support. Activity 6.6: Conduct orientation on child rights, child protection for children in CFS but also in schools.

1. Enhance access to multi sector quality services that take care of needs of victims of Gender Based Violence. 2. Enhance access to legal systems and lawyers. 3. Integrate GBV concepts and actions within humanitarian interventions, including operationalisation of the mechanism taking care of sexual abuse and exploitation. PRO-I11 1) Preventive measure must be built on a thorough analysis of the risks and should - as much as possible - be designed to provide concrete changes in the short/medium term. Changes must be measured in the course of the action. Preventive measure should focus on the increased risks resulting from the crisis, rather than more structural issues. 2) Use the comments field to to describe what measures are foreseen (sensitisation, infrastructure, etc.).3) Number of persons reached by prevention measures must be disaggregated by age and sex at reporting stage.4) If action also includes response activities, please add a custom indicator to reflect this.1) PRO-I12 This indicator covers response to survivors of GBV (women, men, girls and boys).2) Appropriate response is defined as the provision of comprehensive services/assistance based on a thorough analysis of the risks faced by persons. The protection outcome of the response must be well defined. Relevant SOPs (including functional Referral Mechanism) should be followed. 3) Use the comments field to to describe what services (medical, MHPSS, legal, security, etc.), as well as SOPs in place.4) Number of persons must be disaggregated by age and sex at reporting stage.5) If action also includes prevention activities, please add a custom indicator to reflect this.

title.narrative: #Number of survivors who receive an appropriate response to GBV

description.narrative: Activity 2: GBV cases managed through community referral pathway Activity 2.1: Find GBV cases through local women’s associations and CBOs Activity 2.2: Provide case management, psychosocial support, material and cash support for gender-based violence survivors and vulnerable children Activity 2.3: Train health facilities of Survivor-focused case management practices Activity 2.4: Refer survivors of GBV for legal support or mediation through local women’s groups

title.narrative: #Number of persons reached by the implementation of specific GBV prevention measures

description.narrative: Activity 1: Integrated GBV awareness campaigns conducted by training women's associations and strenghten their capacity to conduct community dialogue sessions on GBV/CP. Activity 1.1: Train four existing local women’s associations on GBV, human rights and peace building Activity 1.2: Strengthen organizational capacity of local women’s associations to conduct community dialogue sessions on GBV/CP with community members and duty bearers Activity 1.3: Incorporate GBV awareness in CP campaigns for men, women, boys and girls

1. Protection of conflicted affected populations is reinforced by by reducting aggravating factors through supporting community mechanisms that enhance freedom of movement and provide for physical and moral integrity. 2. Ensure affected population has access to an emergency assitance, ensuring their survival and upholding their security & dignity. 3. Reinforce community based protection mechanisms as well as access to basic services. In comments field:1) Define type of participants (population/authorities/Armed Forces/Armed Groups, etc.).2) Define % increase of knowledge expected.3) Describe subject of training.4) At reporting stage, the number of participants must be disaggregated by age and sex.

title.narrative: #Number of unaccompanied and/or separated children who are reunited with their caregivers OR in appropriate protective care arrangements based on BIA

description.narrative: Activity 3: Strengthening the network of host families for the reunification of unaccompanied and separated children, including training of the heads of these HHs Activity 3.1: Host family identification (Old and New family) Activity 3.2: Training of host familly on Child right, care for education, health etc Activity 3.3: Purchasing and distribution of the Accompanied kit to the host families Activity 3.4: Document and refer the case of unaccompanied children to partner for family seeking Activity 3.5: Organise monthly monitoring of the chldren in the Host Families Activity 3.6: Provide monthly support to host families

title.narrative: #Number of participants showing an increased knowledge on the protection subject in focus

description.narrative: Activity 4: Crisis-affected populations are intensively sensitized on Child Protection and Child Rights while referred cases are taken care of Activity 4.1: Organise the FGD with new CP commitees to identify prevalent CP issues Activity 4.2: Train and Equip Child Protection commitees on Child Right, Child Protection Activity 4.3: In collaboration with the local Child Protection Committees identify CBOs, FBOs and Youth group to conduct sensitization sessions /Campaign on Child Right, Child Protection and especially about cases like children are accused of sorcery, violence against children, child abused, children associated with armed groups and forces, child marriage and child exploitation etc. Activity 4.4: Conduct sensitization campaigns in Child Rights and child protection in town and in the other district of the sub prefecture. Activity 4.5: Conduct an orientation on Child Rights and child protection for local authorities, local administration and community Based organization and teachers

title.narrative: #Number of participants showing an increased knowledge on the protection subject in focus

description.narrative: Activity 5: Child Protection community mechanisms (09) are set up and revitalized and their members trained in child rights, child protection prevention and response to cases Activity 5.1: Identify and form the Child Protection Committee Activity 5.2 Identify and Train of Partners (National NGOs, State partners and Committee of protection) on Child Right, child protection prevention and how to response to case Activity 5.3: Equip partners with working materials Activity 5.4: Organise the monthly with the CP commitees and Partners Activity 5.5: Provide with support to the basic social and health services to assist the referred cases like GBV, Physical violence and abuses, separated and unaccompanied children
Conditional cash transfers can include cash for work, cash for assets and cash for training. CSH-R2 Conditional and unrestricted cash

title.narrative: Number of people benefitting from conditional and unrestricted cash transfers

description.narrative: Activity 1: 1000 households are involved in cash-for-work activities over 4 months, including road and market rehabilitation

Resources that enable people to protect and rebuild their livelihood assets include seeds, livestock, tools, business grant, etc. Any kind of transfer modality (in-kind, voucher, cash) and combination thereof to support, protect and enable the restoration/protection/access of/to livelihood assets.

title.narrative: #Number of people provided with resources to protect and start rebuilding livelihood assets

description.narrative: Activity 1: 1000 households receive cash to use at seeds fairs (gardeners)

title.narrative: Number of people provided with resources to protect and start rebuilding livelihood assets

description.narrative: Activity 2: 250vulnerable women receive cash assistance to start up or increase income generating activities
